content:
üßë‚Äçüíª Daily Prompt [2024-04-29]: Describe your ideal coding environment. Is it in a dark room alone? A coffee shop? A nearby park? An actual office? #daily-prompt

My answer: I've worked on a project that was far too ambitious and was way beyond the skills that I had at the time. I've learned a LOT from that experience and I think I'm a better... employee because of it. I understand now that once you get the ball moving on a larger effort it is very hard to change trajectory.

content:
It's mildly interesting that Silicon Valley doesn't have any submarine cable landings. It seems like the home of most of the giant tech startups would have at least one landing. The closest one is 200 miles south of San Francisco at Morro bay.

https://www.submarinecablemap.com/

#internet #infrastructure

content:
Journey into the depths of the Internet with this incredible map showcasing undersea cables and internet exchanges. I have a new version updated for 2024 with some new styling and updated data but I also made a video that shows how our global internet came to be from 2010 to now.

https://sudorandom.dev/posts/internet-map-2024/

https://youtu.be/dZDSUY-vBgs

#dataviz #maps #internet #infrastructure

content:

Next week. I have a new revision of a dataviz that I've done in the past. I'm going to be vague on this until I publish it :blobshh:

I'm working on a post for two weeks that is a new part of a series where I mess around with gRPC. I think I may surprise some people at the direction I go with this.

It's nice.

card.title: Making Greppable Code
card.description: Meaningful names help make code searchable so think twice before naming everything 'entity'

reblog.content:
The U.S. government is warning that smart locks securing entry to an estimated 50,000 dwellings nationwide contain hard-coded credentials that can be used to remotely open any of the locks. The lock's maker Chirp Systems remains unresponsive, even though it was first notified about the critical weakness in March 2021. Meanwhile, Chirp's parent company, RealPage, Inc., is being sued by multiple U.S. states for allegedly colluding with landlords to illegally raise rents.

https://krebsonsecurity.com/2024/04/crickets-from-chirp-systems-in-smart-lock-key-leak/

account.note: Independent investigative journalist. Covers cybercrime, security, privacy. Author of 'Spam Nation,' a NYT bestseller. Former Washington Post reporter, '95-'09. Signal: briankrebs.07 Twitter: @briankrebs Linkedin: https://www.linkedin.com/in/bkrebs/

fields.name: website
fields.value: https://krebsonsecurity.com

media_attachments.description: The Chirp Systems homepage, which says Increase your NOI with automated curb to couch access control, and features a picture of their app running on a mobile phone.

card.title: Crickets from Chirp Systems in Smart Lock Key Leak ‚Äì Krebs on Security

At current exchange rates ($1.00 = ¬£0.80) this means Brits are receiving 1.6p of American thoughts for just 1p. In this paper we propose an alternative asset pricing model for the marketplace of ideas, considering‚Äî
